loans.name: Milca

texts.es:
Milka is dedicated to the sale of fish but there is currently a shortage making her unable to continue this activity; nevertheless she works as a maid for now. She would like to return to her routine once the city lifts its restriction on fishing since she has many plans for how to improver her sales. In this opportunity she would like to receive a long to improve her dwelling to provide a more comfortable living area to her children.

Translated from Spanish by Eliza Wethey, Kiva volunteer.

Milca, se dedica a la venta de pescado, pero por la temporada y la escasez del mismo, no está ejerciendo esta actividad, sin embargo trabaja en una casa como empleada doméstica. Su deseo de volver a su habitual rutina una vez que concluya la restricción en su ciudad la tiene muy contenta debido a que tiene muchos planes de mejora. En esta oportunidad desea adquirir un préstamo para mejorar su morada a fin de otorgarle un espacio cómodo a sus queridos hijos.

loans.use: Purchase of materials to improve her dwelling

loans.name: Milka

texts.es:
Sra. Milka plants, harvests and sells her products (bananas, yuca, corn and others). She collaborates in the maintenance of her home, with the work of her husband. He is the one that is responsible for planting and taking care of the products when they are ready for sale and also brings the products to her so that Milka can take them and sell them to those who enjoy their products. With that kindness and hard working spirit she has also bought better seeds and rebuilt their humble home so that they may improve their lifestyle.

Translated from Spanish by Eliza Wethey, Kiva volunteer.

La señora Milka, siembra, cosecha y vende sus productos (plátano, yuca, maíz y otros). Ella colabora con el sostenimiento de su hogar y con la labor de su amado esposo ya que él es el encargado de sembrar y cuidar sus productos, cuando ya están listos para salir a vender los trae para que Milka los lleve y los venda a quienes degustan de sus productos. Con esa simpatía y el espíritu trabajador que la caracteriza ha decidido adquirir semillas mejoradas y también refaccionar su humilde hogar para mayor comodidad de los suyos.

loans.use: Purchase of seeds and the remodeling of her humble dwelling

loans.name: Yusufu's Group

texts.en:
Yusufu S., age 31, is married with two children (ages 7 and 4). He has a tailoring business that he started in 1999. He works from 7am to 7pm daily and is able to make a monthly profit of about $65.

Yusufu has taken out two previous loans from Tujijenge Tanzania to start another business of making cement fences. He hopes for a new loan to buy materials for his tailoring business. Yusufu will share this loan with his loan group Mwinyi. In the picture, Yusufu is seated first from the left in a blue shirt.

loans.use: to buy more materials for sewing

loans.name: Domitila

texts.es:
Primer préstamo: http://www.kiva.org/app.php?page=businesses&action=about&id=28900&_tpos=1&_tpg=1

Juana, Domitila y Aurelia son socias del Banco Comunal Belén

Juana es conviviente, tiene 39 años y 6 hijos, Juana vende golosinas de manera ambulatoria en la puerta de un colegio. Además Juana por las noches trabaja eventualmente en una empresa.

Por otro lado Domitila es madre soltera, tiene 37 años y 2 hijos, Domitila vende comida de manera ambulatoria en una calle céntrica de la ciudad. Además vende canchas y gelatinas que ella prepara.

Mientras que Aurelia es casada, tiene 50 años y 7 hijos, Aurelia vende frutas de manera ambulatoria en una carretilla. Además Aurelia se dedica a la crianza de ganado caprino y también vende comida en las ferias.

Juana, Domitila y Aurelia necesitan préstamos de 1000 soles, 600 soles, 600 soles respectivamente, dinero que será invertido en la compra de galletas, caramelos, jugos, aceite, papa, gelatina, frutas.

Los sueños de Juana, Domitila y Aurelia son que sus hijos sean profesionales, tener casa propia.

loans.use: Juana, Domitila y Aurelia necesitan préstamos de 1000 soles, 600 soles, 600 soles respectivamente, dinero que será invertido en la compra de galletas, caramelos, jugos, aceite, papa, gelatina, frutas.

loans.name: Patience

texts.en:
Patience D. sells provisions and is a seamstress. She is a single parent with one child.

Patience is asking for additional capital to purchase more goods for her business.

loans.use: To purchase more goods and increase sales

loans.name: Elena

texts.es:
Sra. Elena is the owner of two moto-taxis but at the same time she also sells fish; she is the mother of four children who are in elementary school. Her husband, Sr. Ulises, is the driver of one of her moto-taxis and transports passengers; in addition he focuses on caring for the taxis. In the future she hopes that her children may become professionals, which is why she sells fish at the market and also administers the moto-taxis to provide everything that is necessary for her children. Elena requires some additional money to invest in the maintenance and care for her moto-taxis and also to improve her stand where she sells fish.

Translated from Spanish by Eliza Wethey, Kiva volunteer.

La señora Elena, es propietaria de dos mototaxis, pero al mismo tiempo se dedica a la venta de pescado, tiene cuatro hijos menores en etapa escolar. Su esposo el señor Ulises es quien se dedica al transporte de pasajeros en uno de sus mototaxis y es quien se dedica al cuidado de sus herramientas de trabajo, en el futuro desea que sus hijos sean profesionales, es por eso que ella vende pescado en un puesto del mercado, así como también administra la feria de su mototaxis, para brindar todo lo necesario a sus hijos.Elena requiere de una suma de dinero el cual invertirá en el mantenimiento y arreglo de su herramienta de trabajo y mejorar su espacio de ventas de pescado.

loans.use: Fix up her moto-taxis and her stand where she continues to sell.

loans.name: Ana

texts.es:
Her incredible dedication to the sale of music videos has made Sra. Ana into a business woman who now has two stands where she sells CDs. She has been dedicated to this business for many years and is now able to help her 3 beautiful children get ahead in life. Now Ana would like to improve and expand her business to one day have her own store where she can send her CDs. She is a single mother and works very hard to ensure that her children may get ahead in life.

Translated from Spanish by Eliza Wethey, Kiva volunteer.

Su ardua dedicación en la venta de videos musicales, ha hecho de la señora Ana una mujer de negocios, ya que cuenta en la actualidad con dos puestos de venta de CDS. Ella se dedica a este negocio desde hace muchos años, y gracias a ésta ocupación está sacando adelante a sus 03 hijos y se siente orgullosa de tener unos hijos lindos y buenos. Ahora Ana se encuentra deseosa de ampliar y mejorar sus negocios. Ella es madre soltera y su ardua labor como padre y madre hacen que salga adelante, quiere seguir creciendo en su negocio, y con el tiempo tener un local propio y amplio para vender sus CDS.

loans.use: Increase her capital to sell more entertainment items

loans.name: Porteñas Group

texts.es:
Very early, around 5:00 a.m. the “Porteñas” association begins their day, working on the preparation of lunches that are later distributed to construction workers and institutions that have placed orders. Most of the women are young but have large families; everyone helps with the business from food preparation until the lunches are distributed.

The “Porteñas” association would like to take on larger orders to obtain larger profits, currently they need a reinforcement in their labor capital in the form of additional helpers for this purpose they are requesting a larger loan. After reaching their sales targets, they are sure this will improve the current difficult economic situation they are facing and hence improve the lives of their families.

Translated from Spanish by Jennie R. Campos, Kiva Volunteer.

Muy temprano alrededor de la 5:00am. la asociación “Porteñas” comienza su día trabajando en la elaboración de almuerzos para luego distribuirlos a empleados de construcciones y/o instituciones que hayan realizado sus pedidos. La mayoria de ellas son jovenes pero con familias bastante numerosas, es así que todos ayudan en el negocio, desde la preparación de los alimentos, hasta la distribución de los almuerzos ya realizados.

La asociación Porteñas quiere recepcionar mayores pedidos para obtener mayores ganancias, de momento no es imposible porq necesitarían un refuerzo en su capital de trabajo además de contratar ayudantes, es por eso que ellas solicitan mayores créditos para este fin. Luego de llegar a sus objetivos de venta, están seguras que mejorarían la actual difícil situación económica que ellas están atravesando y por ende mejorar la vida de sus familias.

loans.use: Employ kitchen helpers and reinforce their capital.

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Pro Mujer Bolivia - Oct 23, 2008)

loans.name: Vivian

texts.en:
Vivian M. sells t-shirts, materials, underwear, shoes, and other clothing items. She is a single mother and looks after two children.

Vivian is requesting a loan to purchase a larger inventory of goods for resale to expand her business.

loans.use: Purchase additional clothing items to expand the business and increase profits

loans.name: Magha

texts.en:
Magha C. is married and a mother of five children. Death and sickness in her family are some of the difficulties she has faced in life. These circumstances rendered her helpless so that she could not work or feed herself, let alone her entire family.
             Inadequate money to pay hospital bills and for the school needs for her children also made her join GHAPE in 2005. Since then, she has successfully borrowed, managed and repaid loans two times. The profit from these loans has helped her solve some of the problems mentioned above. For example, she has been able to pay for her children’s school fees and hospital bills when they are sick.
	C. requests a loan to invest in buying corn, purchasing yam seeds for planting, and also rearing fowl.  She believes her business will succeed because of her many years of experience in the farming business.
She has 18 months to repay the loan. The first installment shall be repaid four months after disbursement.

loans.use: To buy corn, corn seeds, fowl and yams

loans.name: Fomunyoh

texts.en:
Born on the 6th of May, 1970, Fomunyoh M. is married and a mother of four children, all below the age of fifteen. She is also the mother to two adopted children. Due to the death of her only sister who was financially supporting her, things became very miserable for M.. Her husband is not hard working and did not provide for M. and her children. All these factors, together with her low level of education, made her very confused in life. Seeing her plight, several GHAPE members advised her to join the program. She became a member of GHAPE in 2004 and was trained in business and marketing. She took her first loan ($40) in the same year. Since then, she has successfully managed and repaid three loans amounting to $280.
	Requests a loan to invest it in buying cocoa and coffee, and the rearing of pigs and goats. She knows her business is going to be successful because she has customers who come to buy her goods, and take them to the cities. In addition, she has several years of experience in the business.
She has 18 months to pay the loan. The first installment shall be repaid four months after disbursement.

loans.use: To buy cocoa and coffee and to rear pigs and goats.

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Chascañawi Ii Group

texts.es:
Fruit sales is the principal activity of the “Chascañawi” association (translated to Spanish it means big eyes with long eyelashes, in a quechua accent), they have been working with the Pro-Mujer family for more than 10 years.

Every week they travel to the Luribay (La Paz) y Chapare (Cochabamba) to purchase a variety of fruits that are later sold at different open markets throughout the city of La Paz and El Alto. Their children usually conduct the sales since they are no longer attending school and need to staff the stalls while their parents make the aforementioned trips to purchase fruits.

The group needs larger loans to inject capital into their businesses, since the prices of products have dramatically increased. By generating higher revenues it will increase their quality of life as well at their children’s lives.

Translated from Spanish by Jennie R. Campos, Kiva Volunteer.

La venta de fruta es la actividad principal de la asociación “Chascañawi” ( traducido al castellano significa ojos grandes con pestañas largas, en voz quechua) , que trabaja con la familia de Pro-Mujer hace mas de 10 años aproximadamente.

Cada semana viajan a la localidad de Luribay (La Paz) y Chapare (Cochabamba) para adquirir variedad de frutas, para luego ofrecerlas en los distintos mercados de la ciudad de La Paz y El Alto, venta que por lo general la realizan con la ayuda de sus hijos, que muchos de estos tuvieron que dejar sus estudios para atender los puestos de venta mientras sus padres realizan los mencionados viajes para la compra de fruta.

Necesitan mayores créditos para inyectar capital a sus negocios, ya que dichos productos tuvieron una alza elevada en sus precios. Generando mayores ingresos conseguirán mejorar su calidad de vida junto a la de sus hijos.

loans.use: Need more capital to purchase products that have increased in price.

loans.name: Gifty

texts.en:
R. Gifty sells meats, ground nuts, and other products. Her husband works in the salt industry, but his income is not enough to support Gifty and their three children.

She is asking for a loan to purchase additional inventory to increase sales and profits.

loans.use: To increase inventory and expand sales

loans.name: Mary

texts.en:
Mary O. sells goods such as rice, beans, yam, and corn. Mary's husband is a carpenter and they have one child.

Business is going very well and she would like to expand the business by using a loan to purchase a larger inventory of goods.

loans.use: To purchase more goods for sale to increase her business and profits

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Christian Rural Aid Network (CRAN) - Oct 22, 2008)

loans.name: Mantillitas Group

texts.es:
Hand embroidered tablecloths, sheets, pillowcases and shawls, are the principal activities of the “Mantillitas” association (hence the name), they work together and in a responsible way with Pro-Mujer. When they have completed their pieces the group sells them through orders placed by artisanal shops and fairs in the city of La Paz.

The associations dream is to export their products in the interior and external parts of the country. For this they will need larger loans to reinforce their labor capital and acquire materials and have access to training courses and learn how to market their products in a more qualified manner; thereby, achieving personal growth and economic development for the good of their households.

Translated from Spanish by Jennie R. Campos, Kiva Volunteer.

El bordado a mano de manteles, sabanas, fundas de almohadas y el tejido de mantillas, es la principal actividad de la asociación “Mantillitas” (por eso la denominación), que trabaja junto a Pro-Mujer con mucha responsabilidad. Ya finalizados sus trabajos los venden a pedido, en tiendas de artesanía y ferias de la ciudad de La Paz.

El sueño que la asociación, es el de exportar sus productos al interior y exterior del país. Para esto necesitan mayores créditos para reforzar su capital de trabajo para adquirir materia prima y poder acceder a capacitaciones donde aprendan a promocionar sus productos de manera mas calificada. De esta manera logran crecimiento personal y económico, para el bien de sus hogares.

loans.use: Purchase materials and attend professional courses.

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Pro Mujer Bolivia - Oct 26, 2008)

loans.name: Grupo Belén - Carmen, Maritza, Yusli Group

texts.es:
Carmen, Yusil and Maritza are members of the Belén Communal Bank (first loan: www.kiva.org/app.php?page=businesses&action=about&id=28900&_tpos=1&_tpg=1).

Carmen lives with her common-law husband, is 35 years old and has five children. She sells animal intestines, which she buys at the slaughterhouse and then washes before selling them at an outdoor stand.

Yusil lives with her common-law husband, is 21 years old and has a 3-year-old son. She sells haberdashery like necklaces and ear rings, which she gets at wholesale in the markets of Ayacucho city.

Maritza is single and 21 years old. She, along with her sister, run a cebiche (regional dish made with fish and lime) stand on a rented site, which they hope to improve after the loan.

Carmen, Yusli and Maritza are requesting loans of 600, 400 and 1200 soles, respectively, which they plan to use to purchase intestines, toys, tables, chairs, pots and confectionary.

The three women dream of having their own homes, their own stable stores and build their business.

Translated from Spanish by Marty Greenstein, Kiva Volunteer

Primer préstamo: http://www.kiva.org/app.php?page=businesses&action=about&id=28900&_tpos=1&_tpg=1

Carmen, Yusli y Maritza son socias del Banco Comunal Belén.

Carmen es conviviente, tiene 35 años y 5 hijos, Carmen vende tripas de animales, que compra del camal y luego de lavarlas lo vende de manera ambulatoria.

Por otro lado Yusli es conviviente, tiene 21 años y 1 hijo de 3 años, Yusli vende mercería como collares, aretes y los reparte por mayor en los mercados de la ciudad de Ayacucho.

Mientras que Maritza es soltera y tiene 21 años, Maritza junto a su hermana tiene una cebichería en un ocal alquilado, con el préstamo que obtendrá implementara más su negocio.

Carmen, Yusli y Maritza necesitan préstamos de 600 soles, 400 soles, 1200 soles, dinero que será invertido en la compra de tripas, juguetes, mesas, sillas, ollas y reposteros.

Los sueños de Carmen, Yusli y Maritza son tener casa propia, una tienda estable y ampliar sus negocios.

loans.use: Purchase intestines, toys, tables, chairs, pots and confectionary / Carmen, Yusli y Maritza necesitan préstamos de 600 soles, 400 soles, 1200 soles, dinero que será invertido en la compra de tripas, juguetes, mesas, sillas, ollas y reposteros.

loans.name: Mujeres Luchadoras Group

texts.es:
This committee is made up of 18 hard-working women from the Santa Lucia neighborhood of the city of Caacupé. Most of the women own small general stores, while others own kiosks, sell clothing and chipas (a traditional Paraguayan food similar to bread). The group is currently on their third cycle of Fundacion Paraguaya's Entrepreneurial Women program; each woman currently receives an average of 943,000 guaranís (US$231).

The first committee meetings were held in the home of Mrs. Marilyn C.. 22 interested women showed up to the group's first meeting. Then, in the second group meeting, 18 women agreed to sign up and take on the benefits and the responsibilities inherent in the program. Today, they hold weekly meetings whenever possible. It is difficult to find a regular time when they are all free to meet, since most of them are ambulatory vendors and work very long hours, beginning very early in the morning and finishing very late at night.

Though this committee is one of the newest formed at the Caacupé office, the women are already doing all sorts of extra work in order to make contributions to their group savings account. This account is very important, and will be used if any of the committee members has to pay for emergency hospitalizations or medications, or to help women make their repayments so that they do not fall behind.

Each woman will invest her share of the loan to purchase merchandise or raw materials for the particular products she sells.

Translated by Cynthia McMurry, Kiva volunteer.

El comité está integrado por 18 señoras trabajadoras del barrio Santa Lucia de la ciudad de Caacupé, la mayoría de ellas poseen despensas, otras kioscos, ventas de ropa y ventas de chipa (comida típica del Paraguay).El grupo se encuentra actualmente en el 3er. Ciclo del programa Mujeres Emprededoras, y a la fecha todas manejan una línea de crédito promedio de Gs. 943.000 por cada integrante.

Las primeras reuniones del comité se realizaron en el domicilio de la señora Marilyn C. y en esa primera reunión estuvieron más de 22 personas interesadas, luego, ya en la segunda reunión, quedaron finalmente 18 señoras que aceptaron formar parte y adquirir los beneficios y responsabilidad que este programa ofrece. Hoy día ellas se reúnen en lo posible cada semana, buscando siempre un horario que a todas les quede mejor ya que la mayoría de ellas trabajan como vendedoras ambulantes y les resulta difícil disponer de un horario fijo entre semana ya que ellas empiezan su jornada de trabajo a muy tempranas horas de la mañana y terminan tarde por la noche.

Este comité es uno de los más nuevos que se formaron en la Oficina de Caacupé, ellas ya están realizando todo tipo de actividades extras para recaudar fondos para sus ahorros. Estos ahorros son muy importantes ya que los utilizan en caso de que alguna de las integrantes tenga una necesidad como la compra de medicamentos, internaciones, o también para pagar sus cuotas y no atrasarse con los pagos de sus créditos.

Los préstamos que recibirán ellas desean reinvertirlos en sus distintas actividades para la compra de mercaderías para la venta y materia prima para la elaboración de sus productos comestibles.

loans.use: Purchase of foodstuffs such as starch, vegetable oil, cheese, sugar, yerba mate, milk, cookies, beef, soda, and other drinks, as well as clothing for women, men and children.

loans.name: Jacqueline Del Socor

texts.es:
Jacqueline G. is 43 years old and lives in the Villa Reconciliación de Managua; she has 4 children, 2 are independent and 2 are studying. Her life partner is a welding mechanic.

Jacqueline is a small business owner that sells clothing and cosmetics, and sells traditional Nicaraguan dishes, and has been in business for 10 years. She began the business with much effort and her own capital; she began by selling traditional Nicaraguan dishes. In time she established her clothing and cosmetics sales.

Her short term plans are to increase her business by obtaining additional investment capital, and she wishes to provide complete schooling for her 2 children.

Translated from Spanish by Jennie R. Campos, Kiva Volunteer.

Doña Jacqueline Gutiérrez tiene 43 años de edad habita en el barrio Villa Reconciliación de Managua, tiene 4 hijos, de los cuales dos son independientes, y los otros dos aun se encuentran estudiando. Su compañero de vida es mecánico soldador.

Doña Jacqueline es una pequeña comerciante que se dedica a la venta de ropa y cosméticos, a la elaboración de cereales y nacatamales, tiene 10 años como comerciante. Empezó el negocio con esfuerzo y capital propio, sus primeras ventas fueron de nacatamales y cereales. Con el tiempo estableció tambien las ventas de cosméticos y ropa.

Sus planes a corto plazo es poder incrementar las ventas de su negocio a través de la obtención de más capital para invertirlo, y también desea poder darle lso estudios completos a sus dos hijos.

loans.use: Purchase materials to produce traditional Nicaraguan dishes.

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for AFODENIC - Oct 26, 2008)

loans.name: Leticia Jacqueline

texts.es:
Leticia is 53 years old and lives in the region of Sabana Grande. She has 4 children who are attending school; her life partner is a driver and helps with family expenses.

Six years ago Leticia and her partner used their own capital to begin their business by selling chicken. Currently she also works as a dressmaker and hopes that in the future she can expand her sales and dressmaking, as part of this growth she is requesting a loan to buy products and fabrics in order to complete her customers’ dressmaking orders.

Translated from Spanish by Jennie R. Campos, Kiva Volunteer.

Doña Leticia tiene 53 años de edad y habita en la comarca Sabana Grande. Tiene 4 hijos que se encuentran estudiando, su compañero de vida es de oficio conductor y le apoya con los gastos familiares.

Doña Leticia junto a su compañero hace 6 años empezaron el negocio de las ventas de derivados de pollo con capital propio. Actualmente se dedica también a la costura y desea en un futuro poder agrandar sus ventas y sus costuras, y como parte de ese cercimeinto está solicitando el crédito para comprar productos para sus ventas y telas para poder haciendo las costuras solicitadas por sus clientes.

loans.use: Purchase chicken for sales and fabrics for her dressmaking.

loans.name: Martha Lorena

texts.es:
Martha is 45 years old, she lives in the Reparto Shick neighborhood; she is single and has 5 children, 4 are independent while 1 depends on her.

Martha is a caretaker and she also sells snacks and has 7 years of experience. She would like a loan to improve the structure of a room in her home and to purchase materials and zinc. Her goal is to improve her home and standard of living, and to provide her son an education.

Translated from Spanish by Jennie R. Campos, Kiva Volunteer.

La Sra. Martha tiene 45 años de edad, habita en el barrio Reparto Shick, es soltera, con 5 hijos los cuales 4 ya son independientes y uno es el que está a su cargo.

Doña Martha es conserje pero también tiene ventas de golosinas y tiene siete años de experiencia. El préstamo lo quiere para mejorar la construcción del cuarto y compra de perlines, zinc. A futuro es mejorar su vivienda y su nivel de vida y poder brindarle estudios a su hijo.

loans.use: Purchase materials and zinc, to use in her home and improve the structure of a room.

loans.name: Grupo Confianza - Teofila, Rene, Keita Group

texts.es:
TeofiL., Keita and Renee are members of the Confianza (Confidence) Communal Bank (first loan: www.kiva.org/app.php?page=businesses&action=about&id=30238&_tpos=1&_tpg=1).

TeofiL. is married, 58 years old and has 12 children. She sells wool, cheese and meat at an outdoor stand at the Chorro market.

Keite lives with her common-law husband, is 27 years old and has three children. She sells firewood out of her home, and also purchases grains to ship out of town.

Renee lives with her common-law husband, is 36 years old and has two children. She's dedicated to making curtains and linings for furniture. Her store is located in her mother-in-law's home.

TeofiL., Keita and Renee are requesting loans of 1000, 800 and 1000 soles, respectively, which they plan to use to purchase wool, cheese, barley, wheat, fabrics and accessories.

The three women dream of improving and growing their businesses, and having their own home and a store.

Translated from Spanish by Marty Greenstein, Kiva Volunteer

Primer préstamo: http://www.kiva.org/app.php?page=businesses&action=about&id=30238&_tpos=1&_tpg=1

TeofiL., Keita y Renee son socias del Banco Comunal Confianza.

TeofiL. es casada, tiene 58 años y 12 hijos, TeofiL. venD. lana D. oveja, queso, carne D. manera ambulatoria en el M. Chorro.

Por otro lado Keita es conviviente, tiene 27 años y 3 hijos, Keita venD. leña en su casa. Además Keita compra cereales y luego envía a Pisco.

Mientras que Renee es conviviente, tiene 36 años y 2 hijos, Renee se dedica a L. confección D. cortinas, forros para muebles, su tienda esta ubicado en L. casa D. su suegra.

TeofiL., Keita y Renee necesitan préstamos D. 1000 soles, 800 soles, 1000 soles, dinero que será invertido en L. compra D. lana, queso, cebada, trigo, telas y accesorios.

Los sueños D. TeofiL., Keita y Renee son mejorar su negocio, tener casa propia, tener una tienda y ampliar su negocio.

loans.use: Purchase wool, cheese, barley, wheat, fabrics and accessories / Teofila, Keita y Renee necesitan préstamos de 1000 soles, 800 soles, 1000 soles, dinero que será invertido en la compra de lana, queso, cebada, trigo, telas y accesorios.

loans.name: Grupo Confianza - Yeny, Tania, Maura Group

texts.es:
Tania, Maura and Yeni belong to the Confianza (Confidence) Communal Bank (first loan: www.kiva.org/app.php?page=businesses&action=about&id=30238&_tpos=1&_tpg=1).

Tania is married, 32 years old and has two children. She has internet stations in her home and also sells office supplies.

Maura is separate, 27 years old and has a son. She sells groceries at the local fairs once a week, where she also buys grains.

Yeni is 29 years old and single. She sells natural products via catalogue to friends and relatives.

Tania, Maura and Yeni are requesting loans of 1000, 400 and 400 soles, respectively, which they plan to use to purchase office supplies, oil, rice and natural products.

The three women dream to grow their businesses, purchase land and proviD. their children with a good education.

Translated from Spanish by Marty Greenstein, Kiva Volunteer

Primer préstamo: http://www.kiva.org/app.php?page=businesses&action=about&id=30238&_tpos=1&_tpg=1

Tania, Maura, Yeni pertenecen al Banco Comunal Confianza.

Tania es casada, tiene 32 años y 2 hijos, Tania tiene cabinas D. Internet en su casa y además venD. artículos D. librería.

Por otro lado Maura es separada, tiene 27 años y 1 hijo, Maura tiene venD. abarrotes en las ferias 1 vez por semana y D. las ferias compra cereales.

Mientras que Yeni es soltera y tiene 29 años, Yeni venD. productos naturales por catálogo que ofrece a amigos y familiares.

Tania, Maura, Yeni necesitan préstamos D. 1000 soles, 400 soles, 400 soles, dinero que será invertido en L. compra D. artículos D. librería, aceite, arroz y productos naturales.

Los sueños D. Tania, Maura, Yeni son ampliar su negocio, comprar un terreno y brindar una buena educación a sus hijos.

loans.use: Purchase office supplies, oil, rice and natural products / Tania, Maura, Yeni necesitan préstamos de 1000 soles, 400 soles, 400 soles, dinero que será invertido en la compra de artículos de librería, aceite, arroz y productos naturales.

loans.name: Cleide

texts.es:
Cleide is a member of the Santa Rita Communal Bank (first loan: www.kiva.org/app.php?page=businesses&action=about&id=29542&_tpos=1&_tpg=1). She is married, 38 years old and has two children. She runs a carpentry business along with her husband, fulfilling orders to make distinct furniture items. In the past two months they've received orders from institutions, which has helped them increase their earnings. She also works teaching the elderly how to read and write. Cleide is requesting a loan of 1000 soles ($375), which she plans to use to purchase cedar and devilwood. Her dreams are to enlarge her shop and open a furniture store in the city center.

Translated from Spanish by Marty Greenstein, Kiva Volunteer

Primer préstamo: http://www.kiva.org/app.php?page=businesses&action=about&id=29542&_tpos=1&_tpg=1

Cleide es socia del Banco Comunal Santa Rita.

Cleide es casada, tiene 38 años y 2 hijos, Cleide junto a su esposo tienen una carpintería, ubicada en un asentamiento humano, realizan trabajos a pedidos de distintos muebles, en los últimos meses tuvo pedidos de instituciones con lo cual sus ingresos aumentaron. Además Cleide trabaja alfabetizando a personas mayores.

Cleide necesita un préstamo de 1000 soles, dinero que será invertido en la compra de madera cedro y diablo.

Los sueños de Cleide son ampliar su taller y abrir una tienda de muebles en el centro de la ciudad.

loans.use: Purchase cedar and devilwood to make furniture / Cleide necesita un préstamo de 1000 soles, dinero que será invertido en la compra de madera cedro y diablo.

loans.name: Margaret

texts.en:
Margaret A. sells plastic chairs at the local market. She is a single mother and says that it is a good business which makes life worth living for her and her child.

She lacks enough capital to purchase in large quantities and would like a loan to improve her purchasing power and thus increase her profits.

loans.use: To purchase a larger inventory of plastic chairs at lower costs.

loans.name: Maria Gabina

texts.es:
María started her business in order to help her husband with household and personal expenses as well as school expenses for their children. Mayra, 16, studies in secondary school, and 9-year old Alvaro is in primary school; her oldest daughter Carla Susana, 21, works. She started her business more than 3 years ago selling cosmetics to family and friends, little by little sales increased and in this way she has been able to contribute to her children’s education.

She now needs a loan for $250 that she will pay in 3 months in order to buy merchandise and be able to deliver some pending orders.

Translated from Spanish by Diane Lister, Kiva Volunteer.

María inició el negocio para ayudar a su esposo con los recibos de servicios, gastos personales asi como gastos de escuela de sus hijos: Mayra de 16 años cursa la secundaria y Alvaro de 9 años estudia primaria; su hija mayor Carla Susana 21 años, quien trabaja. Comenzó su negocio hace mas de 3 años vendiendo cosmeticos con familiares y amigos, poco a poco fue incrementando sus ventas, y asi ha podido contibuir con la educacion de sus hijos.

Ella necesita un prestamo por US $250 que pagara en 3 meses para comprar mercancia y poder entregar unos pedidos que tiene pendientes.

loans.use: To purchase merchandise

loans.name: Margarita Solola Group

texts.es:
The women who make up the Community Bank Margaritas de Solola live in Solola. Solola is a small town populated mostly by indigenous South American Indians and a well-known commercial centre. Farmers from the surrounding villages bring their small annual harvests to the market at Solola to sell.

Members of this group invest their money in different businesses. For example, there are women who buy yarns for making traditional fabrics. Others buy threads to use in embroidering beautiful Maya designs in traditional clothing. There are also women who invest their money in the purchase and resale of clothing, animal husbandry, and meal preparation. There is even a woman who spends her money on maintaining her “moto-taxi” (motorcycle taxi).

This group of women does believe in the opportunities that the loans provide. To begin with, they believe that without these loans they could never have started their businesses, since their own capital was never sufficient to generate any profit. At a more personal level, many of these women have large families and the income they earn complements that of their husbands’, which is generally insufficient to support the entire family.

These women dream of helping their children study and attend school (and why not university?) and be able to attend school themselves. Once these women see a glimmer of hope, they have no qualms about taking the bull by the horns, as it were, and to try to overcome their difficulties.

Translated from Spanish by MuseAndThinker, Kiva Volunteer

Las mujeres que integran el banco comunal Margaritas de Solola viven en el pueblo de Sololá. Sololá es un pueblo poblado mayormente por indígenas. Este pueblo es muy conocido por el comercio. Los agricultores que tienen sus pequeñas cosechas en pueblos aledaños van a vender sus productos al mercado de dicho pueblo.

Las clientas que trabajan en este grupo invierten su dinero en distintos negocios. Por ejemplo, hay señoras que compran hilos para elaborar tejidos tradicionales. Otras utilizan el hilo para bordar bellos diseños Mayas en la ropa tradicional. También hay señoras que invierten su dinero en la reventa de ropa, crianza de animales y la elaboración de comidas. También hay una señora que invierte su dinero en el mantenimiento de su mototaxi.

Este grupo de señoras realmente cree en la oportunidad que les brinda el crédito. Para empezar ellas piensan que sin el crédito ellas nunca hubieran podido empezar su negocio porque el capital que tenían anteriormente no era suficiente para generar utilidades.

En lo personal ellas piensan que les ha ayudado bastante porque ahora ellas pueden cubrir algunos gastos de la familia. Muchas de las señoras tienen familias grandes y el salario del esposo no da abasto para cubrir los gastos de sus hijos. También ellas piensan que con el dinero que ellas ganan les sirve para apoyar al esposo para proveer las cosas de la casa.

El sueño de las señoras es el de ayudar a sus hijos a que estudien. Ellas quieren que vayan al colegio y porque no a la universidad. Otro sueño que ellas tienen es el que ellas también quieren asistir al colegio.

Una vez que las mujeres ven la luz del desarrollo, ellas empiezan a tomar el toro por las astas

loans.use: Purchase of threads, clothes, ingredients to prepare food and purchase of animals for resale

loans.name: Maria Victoria

texts.es:
Victoria started her business when she realized that her husband’s salary was not enough. They were always having difficulty getting by and were always short of money. Because of this they were not meeting household expenses and school fee payments. She decided to become self-employed in something that would not take her away from home, and so she chose to start selling cosmetics. She started more than 3 years ago with the help of her family who helped her to buy some catalogues and to build up clientele.

She now needs a loan of $250 that she will pay in 3 months in order to buy merchandise and be able to deliver some orders. With your help Victoria can increase her sales.

Translated from Spanish by Diane Lister, Kiva Volunteer.

Victoria inició el negocio cuando se dio cuenta que el sueldo de su esposo era insuficiente y siempre tenian carencia y falta de de dinero, ya que no completaba con los gastos y pagos de escuela. Ella decidio emplearse por su cuenta, en algo que no descuidara su casa, por loq ue decidio empezar con la venta de cosmeticos. Comenzó hace mas de 3 años con apoyo de su familia le ayudaron a comprar unos catalogos y se hizo de clientela.

Ahora necesita un prestamo por US $250 que pagara en 3 meses para comprar mercancia y asi poder entrgar algunos pedidos. Con tu ayuda Victoria podra incrementar sus ventas.

loans.use: To buy merchandise

loans.name: Maria Luisa

texts.es:
Luisa started her business because with her husband’s salary they were not meeting their expenses and were short of money. Since her husband is a carpenter, he does not have a steady income. Faced with this necessity she decided to become self-employed in something that would not take her away from the home too much, and so over 3 years ago with the support of her family who helped her to invest in cheese and sausage, she started with selling these products.

She now needs a loan of $250 that she will pay in 3 months in order to buy more products and in this way continue her business.

Translated from Spanish by Diane Lister, Kiva Volunteer.

Luisa inició el negocio ya que con el sueldo de su esposo no completaba y siempre tenian carencia economicas y falta de de dinero, ya que su esposo es carpintero por lo que no tiene un sueldo fijo. Ante la necesidad ella decidio empelarse por su cuenta, en algo que no descuidara su casa, por lo que hace mas de 3 años con apoyo de su familia le ayudaron a invertir en quesos y chorizo y empezo con la venta de estos productos.

Ahora necesita un prestamo por US $250 que pagara en 3 meses para comprar mas productos y asi continuar con su negocio.

loans.use: To buy more products

loans.name: Maria Luisa

texts.es:
Luisa started her business because she was unemployed and saw the need to cover her personal and home expenses. She has 2 children who are 6 and 4 years old and her husband is a musician in a band that plays at social gatherings; because of this he does not have a steady income. They needed to pay for utility bills among other expenses. She started more than 5 years ago when a brother-in-law encouraged her to sell car audio speakers, and little by little she built up a client base and now makes a good income.

She now needs a loan for $250 that she will pay in 3 months to buy 2 pairs of speakers and deliver a pending order. With your help she can keep her business growing.

Translated from Spanish by Diane Lister, Kiva Volunteer.

Luisa inició el negocio porque se quedo sin empleo y se vio en la necesidad de cubrir los gastos personales y de la casa, tiene 2 hijos de 6 y 4 años y su esposo es musico en una banda que toca en ventos sociales, por lo que su sueldo no es fijo. Ellos necesitaban realizar los pagos de recibos de servicios, entre otras cosas. Comenzó hace mas de 5 años cuando un cuñado la motivo para la venta de las bocinas para autos, poco a poco fue haciendo una cartera de clientes y actualmente obtiene buenos ingresos.

Ella necesita un prestamo por US $250 que pagara en 3 meses para comprar dos pares de bocinas para entregar un pedido que tiene pendiente. Con tu ayuda ella podra hecr crecer su negocio.

loans.use: To buy two pairs of audio speakers

loans.name: Grupo Belén - Domitila, Aurelia, Juana Group

texts.es:
Juana, Domitila and Aurelia are members of the Belén Communal Bank (first loan: www.kiva.org/app.php?page=businesses&action=about&id=28900&_tpos=1&_tpg=1).

Juana is 39 years old, has six children and lives with her common-law husband. She sells snacks at an outdoor stand in front of a school and also works evenings time to time at a local business.

Domitila is a 37-year-old single mother of two. She sells food at an outdoor stand on one of the city's main streets. She also sells a corn dish called cancha and gelatin, which she makes herself.

Aurelia is married, 50 years old, and has seven children. She sells fruits outdoors with a wheelbarrow. She also dedicates herself to raising goats and selling food at festivals.

Juana, Domitila and Aurelia need loans of 1000, 600 and 600 soles, respectively, which they will use to purchase cookies, caramels, juices, oils, potatoes, gelatin and fruit. The dreams of these three women are to have their own homes and for their children to be successful.

Translated from Spanish by Marty Greenstein, Kiva Volunteer

Primer Préstamo: http://www.kiva.org/app.php?page=businesses&action=about&id=28900&_tpos=1&_tpg=1

Juana, Domitila y Aurelia son socias del Banco Comunal Belén

Juana es conviviente, tiene 39 años y 6 hijos, Juana venD. golosinas D. manera ambulatoria en la puerta D. un colegio. Además Juana por las noches trabaja eventualmente en una empresa.

Por otro lado Domitila es madre soltera, tiene 37 años y 2 hijos, Domitila venD. comida D. manera ambulatoria en una calle céntrica D. la ciudad. Además venD. canchas y gelatinas que ella prepara.

Mientras que Aurelia es casada, tiene 50 años y 7 hijos, Aurelia venD. frutas D. manera ambulatoria en una carretilla. Además Aurelia se dedica a la crianza D. ganado caprino y también venD. comida en las ferias.

Juana, Domitila y Aurelia necesitan préstamos D. 1000 soles, 600 soles, 600 soles respectivamente, dinero que será invertido en la compra D. galletas, caramelos, jugos, aceite, papa, gelatina, frutas.

Los sueños D. Juana, Domitila y Aurelia son que sus hijos sean profesionales, tener casa propia.

loans.use: Purchase cookies, caramels, juices, oil, potatoes, gelatin and fruit / Juana, Domitila y Aurelia necesitan préstamos de 1000 soles, 600 soles, 600 soles respectivamente, dinero que será invertido en la compra de galletas, caramelos, jugos, aceite, papa, gelatina, frutas.

loans.name: Felina

texts.es:
Felina, single and 34 years old, finished secondary school and comes from and lives in the Roma annex in La Libertad, Perú. She has a large store in her home, where she sells sweets, beauty products, gifts, etc.

She started with Manuela R. in 2007 with a first loan of S/.300 which was invested in the purchase of groceries. She belongs to the communal bank Romanas Luchadoras II.

With the loan of S./800, to be repaid over a period of six months, she will invest in further supplying her store.

Felina gives thanks to God for all she has, and wants to grow her business each day to be able to help her family.

Translated from Spanish by Mary Lynn, Kiva Volunteer.

La señora Felina, soltera, tiene 34 años, natural del anexo Roma, , cursó estudios secundarios, vive en el anexo Roma Provincia de Ascope La Libertad – Perú. Felina tiene una bodega grande en su domicilio en la cual vende golosinas, artículos de belleza, regalos,etc. Se inició con Manuela R. desde el año 2007 concediéndole un primer préstamo de S/.300.oo, invertido en la compra de abarrotes. Pertenece al Banco Comunal Romanas Luchadoras II”. Con el préstamo de S/. 800., el cual será cancelado en un plazo de 6 meses; lo invertirá en la implementación de su bodega. La señora Felina agradece a Dios por todo lo que tiene hasta ahora y desea que su negocio crezca cada día mas para así poder ayudar a su familia.

loans.use: Purchase more merchandise for her grocery store.

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Manuela Ramos / CrediMUJER - Oct 24, 2008)

loans.name: Rosalinda

texts.es:
Rosalinda started her business due to the need to contribute to the household expenses, given that her husband could not pay for their two children’s educations as well as their living costs. She started 12 years ago with a grocery store in her home, since she had always been good at sales. Over time, she has consolidated and grown her enterprise.

She is now asking for a loan of $775USD to be repaid over a term of six months in order to purchase merchandise. This credit will be very useful to her in continuing to grow as a small business owner. Let’s support Rosalinda.

Translated from Spanish by Mary Lynn, Kiva Volunteer.

Rosalinda inició el negocio por la necesidad de apoyar con los gastos del hogar, ya que su esposo no podia pagar los estudios de sus 2 hijos y los gastos familiares. Comenzó hace 12 años con una tienda de abarrotes en su domicilio ya que ella simpre ha tenido una gran facilidad para las ventas. A lo largo de este tiempo ha consolidado su negocio y lo ha hecho crecer.

Ahora solicita un prestamo por US $775 que pagara en 6 meses para comprar mercancia. Este credito le va ser de gran utilidad para que siga crecindo como microempresaria. Apoyemos a Rosalinda

loans.use: Purchase merchandise.

loans.name: Martha Emperatriz

texts.es:
Martha is married and is 58 years old. She is from La Libertad and finished junior high school. She has 5 children, one of which still depends on her. She lives in the Virgen D. la Puerta neighborhood in the city of Trujillo, Peru. For over ten years, Martha has dedicated herself to selling clothing and renting rooms in her home. She first obtained a loan from Manuela Ramos two years ago which she used to invest in the purchase of clothing for adults. She is a member of the communal bank “San Judas Tadea.” She will use this loan - which she will repay in 4 months - to invest in the purchase of clothing. Martha dreams of improving her living conditions and that her business will grow so that she can some day have a large bazaar.

Translated from Spanish by Cindy M., Kiva Volunteer.

La señora Martha esta casada, tiene 58 años, es natural D. La Libertad, cursó estudios secundarios completos, tiene 05 hijos D. L. cuales una aun depenD. D. ella; vive en la Urbanización Virgen D. la Puerta en la cuidad D. Trujillo – Perú. La señora Martha se dedica a la venta D. ropa y alquiler D. cuartos, lleva mas D. 10 años. Se inició con Manuela Ramos hace dos años concediéndole un primer préstamo D. S/.300, lo invertio en la compra D. ropa para adultos. Pertenece al Banco Comunal San Judas Tadeo”, Con el préstamo D. S/. 400., el cual será cancelado en un plazo D. 04 meses; lo invertirá en la compra D. ropa, para entregar a las personas que acostumbran hacerle L. pedidos. La señora Martha sueña con mejorar sus condiciones D. vida, y que su negocio crezca hasta llegar a tener un bazar muy granD..

loans.use: Purchase of additional merchandise

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Manuela Ramos / CrediMUJER - Oct 25, 2008)

loans.name: Elvira

texts.es:
Elvira started her business to help her husband out with the family’s daily expenses and to give her two children a good start in life. Her husband didn’t have a stable job, and she decided to start making money somehow without having to leave her household responsibilities. Six years ago she began clothing out of small markets, packets of new and used clothes. She currently sells new clothes through catalogue, which brings better profits, although she still sells the packets of clothing too. Thanks to this business she has been able to help her husband with the family’s expenses.

Elvira needs a US $ 250 loan, which she will pay in four months. She plans to invest in more clothing and complete a few orders she has waiting. With your help she will be abel to expand her business.

Translated from Spanish by Nathan, Kiva volunteer.

Elvira inició el negocio para apoyar a su esposo con los gastos de la casa y poder sacar a sus 2 hijos adelante, ya que su esposo no contaba con un empleo fijo, ella decidio emprender una actividad para generar ingresos sin descuidar su casa. Comenzó hace 6 años vendiendo en los mercaditos ropa por pacas de segunda y nueva. Actualmente vende ropa nueva por catalogo, lo que le da mejores ganancias. aunque combina mabas actividades. Gracias a este negocio ha podido ayudar a su marido con los gastos. Ella necesita un prestamo por US $250 que pagara en 4 meses para comprar ropa y surtir algunos pedidos que tiene pendientes. Con tu ayuda ella podra hacer crecer su negocio.

loans.use: Buy clothing for her catalogue sales

loans.name: Marleney Maruja

texts.es:
Marleney is married, 39 years old, comes from La Libertad and finished her secondary school education. She has 2 children still dependent on her, and they live in Virgen de la Puerta in the city of Trujillo, Perú.

Marleney has a grocery store where she sells sodas, mineral water, etc. She has had this business for more than four years. She started with Manuela Ramos in 2006, receiving her first loan of S./300, which she invested in the purchase of sodas and mineral water. She belongs to the communal bank San Judas Tadeo.

With the loan of S./1500, to be repaid over a period of four months, she will invest in supplies for her store.

She dreams of having a larger store and that additional capital investment will help her to increase her income.

Translated from Spanish by Mary Lynn, Kiva Volunteer.

La señora Marleny esta casada, tiene 39 años, natural de la Libertad, cursó estudios secundarios completos, tiene 02 hijos dependientes del hogar; vive en la Urbanización Virgen de la Puerta en la cuidad de Trujillo – Perú. La señora Marleny tiene una bodega en la cual vende,,gaseosa, agua mineral, etc. Este negocio lo tiene más de 04 años. Se inició con Manuela Ramos desde el año 2006 concediéndole un primer préstamo de S/.300., lo invertio en la compra de gaseosas, y agua mineral. Pertenece al Banco Comunal San Judas Tadeo”, Con el préstamo de S/. 1500.00 el cual será cancelado en un plazo de 04 meses; lo invertirá en la implementación de la bodega. La señora Maria sueña tener un local mas grande y con mayores inversiones de dinero que le ayude a incrementar sus

loans.use: Purchase more merchandise to sell.

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Manuela Ramos / CrediMUJER - Oct 25, 2008)

loans.name: Reyes

texts.es:
Reyes started the business to get ahead on her own economically, given that her husband’s work was sporadic and therefore his earnings not enough to support them. Due to this, she was obligated to make progress alone and she decided to start a business selling clothing. She started two years ago selling on order and doing small demonstrations among neighbors and friends until, little by little, she was able to build a customer base.

She now needs a loan of $250USD, to be repaid over a period of four months, to purchase a structure to start selling at the flea markets and outside her home. With your help, she will continue to advance.

Translated from Spanish by Mary Lynn, Kiva Volunteer.

Reyes inició el negocio para salir adelante por si misma por necesidad economica, dado que no era suficiente con lo que ganaba su esposo ya que el no tenia un trabajo fijo lo que la obligo a salir adelante por si misma y decidio emprender un negocio inicio con la venta de ropa. Comenzó hace 2 años solo vendiendo sobre pedidos y pequeñas demostraciones entre los vecinos y amigas hasta que poco a poco logro hacer una cartera de clientes.

Ahora ella necesita un prestamo por US $250 que pagara en 4 meses para comprar una estructura para empezar a vender en los mercados rodantes y afuera de su casa. con tu ayuda ella seguira progresando.

loans.use: To purchase an awning structure.

loans.name: Lucero Marisol

texts.es:
Lucero started her business because of necessity. Her husband’s wages weren’t enough to get ahead so she began to work—out of her house so she could watch over her children. She decided four years ago to sell food to the employees of a nearby company and to students of a nearby school. Little by little her business grew.

Lucero now needs a US $250 loan, to be paid back in four months. She will invest in inputs for her food production and buy two new gas burners. With your support she can do it!

Translated from Spanish by Nathan, Kiva volunteer.

Lucero inició el negocio por necesidad economica dado que el sueldo de su esposo no le alcanzaba para salir adelante y se puse a trabajar por su cuenta en casa, para no descuidar a sus 2 hijos. ella decidio emprender su negocio de venta de comidas Comenzó hace 4 años vendiendo comidas a trabajadores de una empresa aledaña y a una escuela, poco a poco fue incrementando. Ella necesita un prestamo por US $250 que pagara en 4 meses para surtir materia prima y comprar 2 quemadores para su negocio. con tu ayuda podra lograrlo!!.

loans.use: To buy food inputs and two new gas burners

loans.name: Yesenia

texts.es:
Yesenia started her business to get ahead in life and support her parents with their daily expenses. Her father no longer has a stable job and that forced her to take carge of her own life; she started to sell shoes and perfumes by catalog. Two years ago she began going house to house, displaying her merchandise three days per week.

Now Yesenia needs a US $600 loan, to be paid back in six months, to invest in more shoes and perfumes so she can increase her weekly products demonstrations. She also will buy a display case for her merchandise.

Translated from Spanish by Nathan, Kiva volunteer.

Yesenia inició el negocio para salir adelante por si misma para apoyar a sus papas con los gastos familiares de la casa y salir adelante, ya que su papa no tenia un trabajo fijo esto la obligo a salir adelante porsii misma y empezo vender por catalogo. Comenzó hace 2 años vendiendo casa por casa hasta realizar demostraciones 3 dias por semana de perfumes y zapatos. Ahora necesita un prestamo por US$ 250 que pagara en 4 meses, para comprar mercancia y realizar demostraciones mas de 3 veces por semana ademas de un estante de exhibicion para ventas.

loans.use: To invest in shoes and perfumes for her catalogue sales and a new display case

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To inject capital in her grocery store so as to move it forward.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Purchase of natural medicines for her small business.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy natural medicines to retail in her community.

loans.name: Esthela

texts.es:
Esthela started her business to add an additional source of income. Her husband no longer has a stable job, and surely they fought hard to maintain the education costs of their children and when someone got sick. She began on year ago by herself, making and selling tamales.

Now Esthela is applying for a six month US $600 loan to buy ingredients for her tamales and to buy a larger steamer.

Translated from Spanish by Nathan, Kiva volunteer.

Esthela inició el negocio para poder tener un ingreso adicional, ya que su esposo al no tener un trabajo estable y seguro batallaban mucho debido a los gastos de la escuela de sus hijos y tambien gastos cuando se me enfermaban. Comenzó hace mas de un año, por iniciativa propia con la elaboracion y venta de tamales.

Solicita un prestamo por US $600 que pagara en 6 meses para poder surtir mas materia prima y poder comprar una vaporera mas grande.

loans.use: Buy ingredients for her tamale sales, and invest in a larger steamer

loans.name: Gloria Elizabeth

texts.es:
Gloria started her business to improve the lives of her and children, and give her children a good education as a single mother. She began five years ago selling fried food and coconuts from her house, and little by little increased her sales. Now she has a small grocery store with a great variety of products.

Now Gloria is applying for a six month US $600 loan to invest in merchandise for her store. She would like to add gift products in her store. You can make it possible with your support.

Translated from Spanish by Nathan, Kiva volunteer.

Gloria inició el negocio por salir adelante por si misma, a sus 2 hijos y brindarles educacion, como madre soltera.Comenzó hace cinco años vendiendo frituras y cocas en su casa hast que poco a poco empezo a vender mas mercancia hasta poder tener su tienda de abarrotes bien surtida.

Ahora ella solicita un prestamo por US $600 que pagara en 6 meses para comprar mercancia ya que quiere vender algunos regalos, y articulos tipo merceria. Con tu apoyo esto sera posible.

loans.use: Invest in merchandise for her small grocery store

loans.name: Comite San Bernardino Ii Group

texts.es:
This committee is made up of 17 hard-working women from the Centro neighborhood of the city of San Bernadino. Most of the women sell clothing, while others sell jewelry, sweets, chipas (a traditional Paraguayan food, similar to bread) and jams. Guayaba is the most popular flavor of jam; other flavors include strawberry, orange and custard apple.

All of the committee members are neighbors; they are currently on their seventh cycle in the Entrepreneurial Women program run by Fundación Paraguaya. The group was formed thanks to the efforts of Mrs. Zulma B., the group's coordinator, who provided the venue for and organized the first committee meetings. Each woman will receive an average of 882,000 guaranís (US$216).

This group of women is very organized. They perform all of their work very harmoniously, which means that their efforts are always successful. With each additional task that the women perform, they receive extra money for their group savings account. Each woman is very punctual in making repayments and attends a weekly informational group meeting. If one of them misses a meeting without good reason, she will be fined. The women came up with this policy on their own and unanimously agreed on its implementation.

Today, the women are looking for another group loan in order to invest in their various individual commercial activities and buy raw materials to make their products. Among the products to be purchased are fruits like guayabas, custard apples, apples, oranges, dulce de leche, sugar, extracts, starch, cheese, flour, clothing (jerseys, pants, shirts) and jewelry (earrings, rings).

Translated by Cynthia McMurry, Kiva volunteer

El comité está compuesto por 17 señoras trabajadoras del barrio Centro de la ciudad de San Bernardino, la mayoría de las integrantes de este comité se dedica a la venta de ropas, otras venden joyas, otras elaboran y venden chipas (comida típica de nuestro país bastante consumida parecido al pan), otras dulces y mermeladas de frutas como guayaba que es la más vendida, frutilla, mamón, naranja, etc.

Todas las integrantes son vecinas del mismo barrio y actualmente están en el 7 ciclo del programa comité de Mujeres Emprendedoras que maneja la Fundación Paraguaya. Actualmente reciben un promedio de Gs. 882.000 por personas. El grupo se formó gracias a la señora Zulma B. quien fue la coordinadora del grupo y la que facilitó el local y los medios para realizar las primeras reuniones del comité.

Este grupo de mujeres se caracteriza por ser muy organizado, cada actividad que realizan la llevan a cabo con mucha armonía lo que les proporciona siempre de un éxito seguro. Con cada actividad extra que realizan ellas obtienen un dinero extra para su ahorro grupal. Ellas son muy puntuales en sus pagos, y todas asisten a las reuniones informativas que se realizan semanalmente; la ausencia injustificada de alguna de las integrantes recibe una amonestación, esto es, una política implementada por ellas y para la cual todas se pusieron de acuerdo en acatar.

Ellas hoy desean adquirir un crédito nuevo para poder invertirlo en sus actividades comerciales individualmente y comprar mercaderías y materia prima para elaborar sus productos. Entre los productos a adquirir citamos: frutas diversas como guayabas, mamones, manzanas, naranjas, dulce de leche, azúcar, esencias, almidón, queso, harina, leche, ropas y joyas para la venta como remeras, pantalones, camisas, pulseras, aros, anillos, etc.

loans.use: Purchase clothing, gold and silver jewelry, starch, cheese, vegetable oil, sugar, fruit, milk, etc.

loans.name: Angelina

texts.es:
Angelina is 42 years old and married to Mr. Miguel González, who is 46. The couple has four children, all of whom are in high school. 

Angelina has two dreams: the first is to own her own supermarket, and the second is to see all of her children graduate. 

Angelina began working selling merchandise imported from Argentina. During that time she learned many things, above all how to treat customers. Years later, Angelina saw a business opportunity in her neighborhood and decided to open a general store in her house. Angelina already had a group of customers who trusted her because of her previous work, all of whom supported her new business venture; this is how she went about forming a regular customer base.

The loan money will be used to buy items typical of a general store, for example, rice, pasta, milk, bread, soft drinks, cheese and eggs.

Translated by Cynthia McMurry, Kiva volunteer

La Sra. Angelina cuenta con 42 años de edad, está casada  con el Sr. Miguel González de 46 años de edad. La pareja tiene cuatro hijos que actualmente van a la secundaria.

Angelina tiene dos sueños; el primero es ser dueña de un supermercado y el segundo es ver a sus hijos graduados.

Angelina inicio trabajando como vendedora de mercaderías importadas de la Argentina. Durante ese periodo aprendió muchas cosas sobre todo como tratar a los clientes. Anos después Angelina vio una gran oportunidad de negocios en su barrio y entonces decidió abrir una despensa. La despensa esta localizada en su casa. Debido a que Angelina ya tenía clientes que confiaban en ella de su trabajo anterior, todos le apoyaron co su nuevo emprendimiento y así fue formando una clientela. 

El dinero proveído por el crédito será invertido para la compra de artículos comunes en una despensa como por ejemplo: arroz, fideo, leche, pan, gaseosas, queso, huevo, etc.

loans.use: Purchase merchandise such as rice, pasta, oil, eggs, milk, soft drinks and cookies.

loans.name: Rosa Ilda

texts.es:
First loan: http://www.kiva.org/app.php?page=businesses&action=about&id=30341&_tpos=1&_tpg=1

Rosa is a member of the Community Bank Nobleza.

Rosa cohabits with her partner: she is aged 36 and has three children. Rosa sells construction materials such as sand, bricks and she also produces artesanal bricks in the district of Pacaycasa, undertaking the firing of the bricks in a hired oven: her products are delivered to homes according to order.

Rosa needs a loan of 1600 sols, money which will be invested in the purchase of firewood which will be used to fire the bricks.

Her savings will be used to make home improvements.

Rosa’s dream is to purchase a car to transport her products in, expand her business and see her children become professionals.

Translated from the Spanish by Katy Long, Kiva Volunteer

Primer préstamo: http://www.kiva.org/app.php?page=businesses&action=about&id=30341&_tpos=1&_tpg=1

Rosa es socia del Banco Comunal Nobleza.

Rosa es conviviente, tiene 36 años y 3 hijos, Rosa vende materiales de construcción como arena, ladrillos y también se dedica a la fabricación de ladrillos artesanales en el distrito de Pacaycasa y el quemado lo realiza en un horno alquilado, sus productos son repartidos a domicilio según pedido.

Rosa necesita un préstamo de 1600 soles, dinero que será invertido en la compra de leña para quemar los ladrillos.

Sus Ahorros los utilizara para mejorar su casa.

Los sueños de Rosa son comprar un carro para transportar sus productos, ampliar su negocio y que sus hijos sean profesionales.

loans.use: Rosa needs a loan of 1600 sols, money which will be invested in the purchase of firewood which will be used to fire the bricks.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To invest in dental care products in an attempt to expand her small business.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To invest in natural medicines to sell in her community

loans.name: Margarita

texts.es:
Margarita started her business to give her children a good start in life. Due to questions of fate, she had separated from her husband, and then had to provide for her children and cover the costs of their education. She began three years ago after being invited to a course in handicrafts and that’s how she began to enjoy this activity. She began to commercialize her products and has earned good profits since.

Margarita needs a US $600 loan, which she will pay back in six months, to buy material to make handbags, pencil cases, and other cloth goods. With your help, Margarita will improve her family’s situation.

Translated from Spanish by Nathan, Kiva volunteer.

Margarita inició el negocio para poder sacar adelante a sus hijos, ya que por cuestiones del destino se separo de su pareja, y despues de eso tenia que sacar adelante a sus hijos y poderles cubrir los gastos de estudio de ellos. Comenzó hace tres años cuando por invitacion de unas amigas acudio a un curso de manualidades y de ahí le surgio el gusto por esta actividad, por lo que empezo a comercializarlas y ha obtenido buenas ganancias por esto.

Ella necesita un credito por US $600 que pagara en 6 meses para poder comprar material para hacer bolsas, cepilleros, portalapices, etc. Con tu ayuda Margarita sacara a su familia adelante.

loans.use: Invest in materials for her handicraft sales

loans.name: Kuña Katupyry De Luque Group

texts.es:
When Mrs. Blanca G. found out about Fundación Paraguaya's women's committee program, she didn't skip a beat. She contacted all of her female friends in the area to tell them about it and organized an informational meeting about the program.

This group is made up of 15 women who are involved in a variety of economic endeavors. Each woman will invest the money in her individual business. For example, Mrs. Hilaria D., Mrs. Erenia B., and Mrs. Maria A. all own general stores and will invest their money in merchandise like oil, rice, pasta, flour and yerba mate.

Mrs. Patrocina Costa sells vegetables; Mrs. Gloria T. sells women's lingerie; Mrs. Fidelina G. sells food; Mrs. Patricia C. sells drinks.

Mrs. Victoria Galeno, Mrs. Mima C., Mrs. Carolina C. and Mrs. Francisca A. sell clothing, while Mrs. Maria Sachelaridi sells coal.

Mrs. Fatima G. sells handicrafts and will invest her money in raw materials for her art.

Mrs. Basilia Brito and Mrs. Nilda Caceres are seamstresses and will invest their money in articles needed for their work, such as fabric, thread and buttons.

Translated by Cynthia McMurry, Kiva volunteer

Cuando la señora Blanca G. se entero del programa del comité de mujeres que ofrece Fundación Paraguaya no dudo en contactar a sus amigas de la zona para ponerlas al tanto, también organizó una reunión para informarlas acerca del programa.

El grupo esta conformado por 15 mujeres que se dedican a diversas actividades económicas. Cada una de ellas invertirá el dinero otorgado por el crédito de acuerdo a los negocios que manejan. Por ejemplo: La señora Hilaria D., Erenia B., Maria A. son dueñas de despensas e invertirán su dinero en la compra de mercaderías como aceite, arroz, fideos, harina, yerba, etc.

La señora Patrocina Costa se dedica a la venta de verduras; la señora Gloria T. vende lencería, Fidelina G. comestibles y Patricia C. bebidas.

Las señora Victoria Galeno, Mirna C., Carolina C. y Francisca A. se dedican a la venta de ropa, mientras que la señora Maria Sachelaridi se dedica a la venta de carbón.

La señora Fátima G. se dedica a la artesanía e invertirá su dinero en la compra de materia prima para su elaboración.

La señora Basilia Brito y Nilda Caceres son modistas e invertirán en la compra elementos para su trabajo como telas, hilos, botones, etc.

loans.use: Purchase a variety of merchandise: sugar, oil, pasta, drinks, milk, eggs, meta, lingerie, fabric, buttons, zippers, thread and coal.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Purchase of natural medicines to move a small business forward.

loans.name: Zulma Janeth

texts.es:
Zulma started her business because, upon getting married, the couple was left with expenses that had to be paid and also to be able to buy their furniture and materials to build a room onto her mother-in-law’s house where they live. They needed to pay debts and to furnish their home. So, almost two years ago, on her own initiative, she started her business selling whites (towels, sheets, curtains, tablecloths, bed ensembles, etc.).

Now she needs a loan for US$600, which she plans to repay in six months, to invest in merchandise. With your help Zulma will make her business grow.

Translated from Spanish by Hugh Yarbrough, Kiva Volunteer.

Zulma inició el negocio porque al casarse les quedaron compromisos que tenia que pagar y para poder comprar sus muebles, y comprra material para construir un cuarto en la casa de su suegra en donde viven, ellos necesitaban pagar deudas y poder comprar los muebles de su hogar. Entonces hace ya casi dos años por iniciativa propia emprendio su negocio de venta de blancos.

Ahora necesita un prestamo por US $600 que pagara en 6 meses para invertirlo, comprando mas mercancia ( toallas, sabanas, cortinas, manteles, juego de colchas). Con tu ayuda Zulma hara crecer su negoico.

loans.use: Purchase merchandise to sell

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To expand a business by adding natural medicines.

loans.name: Leonor

texts.es:
Despite his 71 years, Leonor C. continues to work hard with the spirit of a young man. He has been married to his wife, Victoriana Ferreira Romero, for thirty years. The couple has no children.

Leonor is an long-standing client of Fundación Paraguaya, which has lent to him since 1997. The couple runs a well-established general store. Income from the store is usually reinvested to purchase more merchandise, which the couple is able to do due to the small size of their family.

The couple has plans to expand their business by introducing a wider variety of merchandise to sell. The loan money will be invested in different foodstuffs and miscellaneous sewing and household supplies.

Translated by Cynthia McMurry, Kiva volunteer

Leonor C. es un señor que a pesar de sus 71 años de edad continua trabajando duro con un espíritu muy joven. Se encuentra casado hace treinta años con Victoriana Ferreira Romero. La pareja no tiene hijos.

Leonor es un cliente antiguo de la Fundación Paraguaya, opera desde el año 1997. La pareja es dueña de una despensa bien consolidada. Generalmente los ingresos de la despensa vuelven a reinvertirlo en compra de mercaderías, debido a que es una familia muy reducida esto se hace más fácil.

La pareja tiene planes de expandir su negocio, aumentando la variedad de artículos. Es por eso que el dinero del crédito otorgado será invertido en artículos comestibles y de mercería.

loans.use: Purchase flour, sugar, corn, fruits and vegetables as well as scissors, buttons and toys, among other things.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To expand her small business by adding natural medicines.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: The funds will be invested to buy natural medicines for a small business.

loans.name: Cipriano

texts.es:
Cipriano started the business because of the need to have more income since work as a bricklayer did not leave him with enough to pay household expenses and the education of his two children. So he took on the task of looking for other work because the money he had wasn’t sufficient and he felt a great deal of pressure. It occurred to him that selling clothing could be a good business and so he decided to start bringing clothes from San Juan de los Lagos, Jalisco, because there he could get them cheaper by volume and could make more money. He started the business two years ago and has done very well because up until now he hasn’t lacked clients that place orders for clothing, even more so now that it’s the summer season. The demand is greater and there are people that order clothes for their entire family.

He needs loan for US$675, which he plans to repay in six months, to buy merchandise. With your help, Cipriano will continue to prosper.

Translated from Spanish by Hugh Yarbrough, Kiva Volunteer.

Cipriano inició el negocio por la necesidad de tener mas ingresos ya que el trabajo de albañileria no le dejaba lo suficiente para solventar los gastos del hogar y de la educacion de sus 2 hijos, asi que tuvo que darse a la tarea de buscar otro trabajo ya que el dinero que tenia ya no le alcanzaba y la presion que tenia era muy fuerte, entonces se le ocurrio que la venta de ropa podria ser un buen negocio por lo que decidio empezar a traer ropa de San Juan de los Lagos, Jalisco; ya que en este lugar la conseguia mas barata por volumen y podia obtener mejores ganancias. Comenzó el negocio hace dos años y le ha ido muy bien ya que hasta ahora no le han faltado clientes que le hagan sus encargos de ropa y sobre todo ahora que es temporada de verano la demanda es muy grande y hay personas que le encargan la ropa para toda su familia.

El necesita un prestamo por US $675 que pagara en 6 meses para comprar mercancia. Con tu ayuda Cipriano seguira prosperando.

loans.use: Purchase clothing to sell

loans.name: Manuela

texts.es:
Manuela B. is a former client of Paraguayan Foundation and received her first loan in 1996. She has been married to Aurelio Arias Notari for more than ten years and they have a son who attends school.

Manuela is a seamstress. She makes many types of clothing, primarily school uniforms, as several schools are her exclusive clients. She makes school shorts, t-shirts, trousers, etc. Manuela’s business is not the only source of family income; Aurelia, her husband, owns a warehouse selling building materials.

This loan will be used for the purchase of fabrics, buttons, and yarns for making clothes.

Translated from Spanish by MuseAndThinker, Kiva Volunteer

Manuela B. es una antigua cliente de Fundación Paraguaya, que en el ano 1996 solicito su primer crédito. Hace mas de 10 anos contrajo matrimonio con Aurelio Arias Notari. La pareja tiene un hijo que va al colegio.

Manuela es confeccionista; hace todo tipo de ropas generalmente uniformes escolares debido a que los colegios son sus clientes exclusivos. Confecciona shorts, remeras, pantalones, etc. Las confecciones de Manuela no son la única fuente de ingreso de la familia. Aurelio es dueño de un depósito donde vende materiales de construcción.

El dinero solicitado será utilizado para a compra de telas, botones, hilos para la confección de ropas.

loans.use: Purchase of fabric and other clothing materials

loans.name: Norma Iliana

texts.es:
Norma has been selling cosmetics for four years because she needed to help her husband with household expenses. Besides that, she has an eleven-month-old son and needs to spend as much time as possible at home so she makes sales to her family and friends. Her husband’s name is Francisco Javier Hernández Saldaña; he works in a company and they have three children – 12, 10 and 11 months, all boys.

Now she needs a loan for US$500, which she plans to repay in six months, to purchase merchandise and deliver some orders. With your help Norma will make her business grow.

Translated from Spanish by Hugh Yarbrough, Kiva Volunteer.

Norma tiene 4 años dedicandose a las ventas de cosmeticos, porque necesitaba ayudar a su marido con los gastos de la casa ademas tiene un niño de 11 meses y necesita estar el mas tiempo posible en su casa asi que las ventas las hace con su familia y amigos. Su esposo se llama Francisco Javier Hernandez Saldaña trabaja en una empresa y tienen 3 hijos de 12, 10 y 11 meses, son niños.

Ahora necesita un prestamo por US $500 que pagara en 6 meses para comprar mercancia y entregar algunos pedidos. Con tu ayuda Norma hara crecer su negocio.

loans.use: Purchase cosmetics to sell

loans.name: María Mercedes

texts.es:
Maria Mercedes is a 22-year-old university student, studying international trade. Despite her youth, she is a successful entrepreneur.

Maria began working with her father when she was younger. However, she did not enjoy it as she did not want to be economically reliant on anyone and decided to work independently. Currently, she sells women’s clothing from various locations and has well-established and diverse customers.

Maria dreams of finishing her studies and opening her own clothing store. She is not far from fulfilling her dreams. She knows that by constant effort she will gradually achieve her goals.

Translated from Spanish by MuseAndThinker, Kiva Volunteer

María Mercedes es una chica de 22 años de edad, estudiante universitaria de la carrera comercio exterior. A pesar de su corta edad es una exitosa emprendedora.

María Mercedes comenzó a trabajar desde joven con su padre. Esta idea no le agradaba mucho, María Mercedes quería ser económicamente independiente. Fue así como decidió trabajar de manera independiente. Actualmente se dedica a la venta de ropas para mujer de manera ambulante. Hoy día cuenta con una clientela bien consolidada y variada.

Ella sueña con poder terminar su carrera y abrir una tienda de ropas. María Mercedes no está muy lejos de alcanzar sus sueños. Ella es conciente que con el esfuerzo diario poco a poco se va cumpliendo sus metas.

loans.use: Purchase of T-shirts, shirts, dresses, jeans, belts, blouses, jackets, etc.

loans.name: María Concepción

texts.es:
Concepción had a job as a teacher, but she liked sales and sold to people she knew after she retired, so she decided to work full time selling shoes from a catalog. This keeps her active and she gets to meet people every day. She has done well with this activity.

She is requesting a loan for US$300, which she plans to repay in four months, to invest in merchandise and increase the size of her business in order to sell more.

Translated from Spanish by Hugh Yarbrough, Kiva Volunteer.

Concepcion tenia un trabajo como maestra, pero le gustaban las ventas y vendia a sus conocidas despues la jubilaron, asi que decidio dedicarse por completo a la venta de zapatos por catalogo, ya que esto la mantiene activa y conoce gente a diario y le ha ido bien con esta actividad.

Ella solicita un prestamo por US $ 300 que pagara en 4 meses para poder invertir en mercancia, agrandar su negocio y asi vender mas.

loans.use: Purchase merchandise

loans.name: Mujeres Trabajadoras Cañada San Rafael Group

texts.es:
